membrane protein that move ions against their concentration gradients Importance of ion pumps b several inorganic ions have steep distribution gradients across the cell membrane ion pumps and ATP play a critical role in maintaining those transmembrane concentrations gradients all have an ATPase activity auto-catalyzes phosphorylation of the pump → driving the cycle of conformational change Na, K-ATPase and Ca-ATPase are regulated by auxiliary protein Na, K-ATPase Ca-ATPase H,K-ATPase Structure of P-type Ion Pumps 10 transmembrane helices and 3 cytoplasmic domains P-domain: phosphorylation domain N-domain: nucleotide-binding domain A-domain: actuator domain Ca-ATPase pump two binding site for Ca2+ a large intracellular domain contains the ATPase enzyme that hydrolyzes ATP conformational change cause binding site moved from facing intracellular space to extracellular region and reduction of affinity for Ca2+ the most important transport system in mammalian cells creates most of the nonequilibrium ion distributions produce electric potential energy critical for electrically excitable cells ion gradient that facilitate secondary active transporters single biggest user of ATP - especially in neurons because of the constant electrical activity and associated ion fluxes
Electrogenic pump net movement of one positive ion out of the cell per cycle → electrical current
Mechanism of Na, K-ATPase two main state, E1 and E2 E1 state ion binding site have high affinity for sodium ions outer gate close, inner gate open
autophosphorylation caused large structural rearrangement → E2 during transition, both gates are closed E2 state binding sites have reduced affinity for sodium outer gate open, sodium flow out ion binding sites now have high affinity for potassium auto-dephosphorylation mediated by hydrolysis with water molecules conformational change → inner gate open inorganic phosphate(Pi) initially remains trapped within the ATP binding pocket release during transition back to E1 state, followed by binding of new ATP molecule large conformational change limit the transportation rate poisoned or inhibit pump → cell death palytoxin bind to pump and caused open of both gates simultaneously turning it into cation channel dissipate a cell's ionic gradient Plasma membrane Ca2+ ATPase (PMCA) Sarco/Endoplasmic Reticulum Ca2+ ATPase (SERCA) actively pumping Ca2+ out of the cell
creating an approximately 1:10,000 gradient inCa2+ ion concentration gradient In cardiac myocytes (cardiac muscle cells) during cardiac contraction, Ca2+ channel remains open Ca2+ ions enter cardiac myocytes Ca2+ pumps return Ca2+ ions back to the lumen of the sarcoplasmic reticulum high concentration of Ca-ATPase pump are required in the SR membrane to keep up with the Ca2+ release Reduced of blood flow for a short period of time during heart attach can caused significant damage to cardiac muscle fails to meet the energy demands of the Ca-ATPase pump closest related to Na, K-ATPase and function similarly exchange two protons for two K+ ions more limited distribution in the body primarily involved in acid secretion by specialized cells in the stomach and kidneys

item.title: Cell Membrane
item.description:
[!Info]Major Function The cell membrane act as an effective barrier to the transport of ions and polar molecules between intracellular and extracellular fluid
Phospholipids A hydrophilic head and a hydrophobic tail - aka amphipathic molecules Lowest energy arrangement hydrophobic tails point in towards the center of the bilayer minimizing the interaction with water molecules Barrier to the diffusion of many biological important molecules interior lipid bilayer is almost impermeable to the diffusion of polar or charged molecules hydrophobic molecules can pass easily
The hydrophobic core as a low relative permittivity (dielectric constant) poor ability to store electrical energy when subjected to an electric field Amphipathic molecules Integral membrane protein Transmembrane protein cross the membrane to the extracellular surface Glycoprotein: covalently linked to carbohydrates on their extracellular surface Peripheral membrane protein - located on the inner surface of the cell membrane - linked to cytoskeletal protein → control cell shape and motility Translocator complex (Translocon) important for achieving the correct topology of the protein in the membrane
Translocation of the growing peptide occurs co-translationally assisted by oligosaccharyl transferase and ER resident membrane chaperones (calnexin) to achieve glycosylation, ensure proper folding and topology Recognition and transfer of integral membrane by signal recognition particle (SRP) Integral membrane are synthesized by the ribosomes The first transmembrane (TM) domain of the nascent peptide functions a targeting sequence for SRP SRP binds to SRP receptor in the ER membrane The ribosome complex and nascent peptide is transferred to the translocon located in the ER Translocation of TM domain the first TM sequence function as a start-transfer signal displaces a plug on the inner surface of the channel that normally gates the translocon channel transfer peptide until it encounters a stop-transfer signal Peptide accumulate on the cytoplasmic side until the next start-transfer signal

item.title: Channels
item.description:
Simplest membrane transport proteins solute can move in or out of the cell through the lumen of the channels Generally specific for their function prevent loss of ion gradients and influx of calcium Three main types Ion channels Water channels (aquaporins) Gap junction channels usually specific to a subset of ions anions or cations, or specific to only one particular type of ion Specificity depends on the binding sites of the channel
Ion channels is also known as gating have the ability to open or close in response to a specific stimulus Leak channels - the channels that are open and passing ions at resting state only a small number, predominantly K+ selective Key role of ion channels - Generating electrical excitation Why do we need separate channels specific for potassium and sodium? The main function of these ion channels is to mediate current flow across the membrane to produce electrical activity Potassium and Sodium flow through channel in only one direction - down their concentration gradient
-Potassium channel mediate the outward flux of potassium - generating an outward current Sodium channels mediate the inward flux of sodium generating an inward current Having two types of ion selective channels allow the cell to manipulate the membrane potential for electrical signaling or other purpose selectively pass water molecules across the membrane
flow of water into or out of the cell is the primary determinant of changes in cell volume generally always open Regulate the water permeability of the membrane by increasing or decreasing the number of aquaporins large non-selective channels freely pass ions and small metabolites between cells connect the cytoplasm of one cell to another no net loss of small metabolites or ions from the cells not normally open to the extracellular solution

item.title: Action potential in Axon
item.description:
Self-propagating wave of depolarization Route of electrical information presynaptic nerve terminal → dendrites/cell body → axon → nerve terminal
Action potential initiates in the initial segment rich in Na+ channels depolarizing neighboring axon membrane → self-propagating current inject into the center of axon can: flow along the interior of the axon flow back to ground across the membrane The ratio of current flow along the axon vs flow across the membrane
depends on the membrane resistance relative to axial path resistance Injected current will have a steadily decreasing influence on the membrane potential with increasing distance from the site of injection
Length Constant the distance over which the steady-state membrane potential drops to 37% of the original amplitude rm = membrane resistance ra = axial resistance conduction properties are the best when ra is small and rm is large decrease axial resistance and increase membrane resistance axon is not a very good conductors voltage will decrement by ~95% within 1-2mm of the site of injection the artificial injection of a current at one point cause current flow for some distance from the point of injection distance depend on length constant local circuit current flow acts to depolarize the neighbor cell membrane - membrane potential of neighbor region is pushed above the threshold by local circuit flow → initiating an action potential
one-way flow of action potential this is achieved by the refractory period properties of action potential the membrane region behind the action potential is in refractory period unable to support a new action potential Orthodromic action potential action potential travels from cell body down the axon towards the nerve terminal Antidromic action potential action potential propagating in the opposite direction from the nerve terminal to the cell body Membrane Resistance - Myelination → increase membrane resistance → increase speed Myelin forming cells (glial cells) form a sheath around axon → acting as an insulator reduce capacitance → increase resistance nodes of Ranvier periodic breaks in the myelin sheath sodium channels clustered at the nodes of Ranvier absent in the internodal membrane Saltatory conduction propagation of action potential leaps from node to node
conduction is fast between nodes and slow down in the node Myelinated axons are metabolic efficient Ion channels clustered at the nodes of Ranvier less energy required by Na,K-ATPase to maintain ion gradient If channels are spread through the membrane a lot of energy will be required to maintain the gradient because of the large surface area to volume ration in axon Axial resistance increase diameter → reduce axial resistance → increase speed usually limited because of space

item.title: Membrane Transport
item.description:
Three major classes of transport protein Channels facilitate diffusion of ions and water molecules down their concentration gradient by creating selective pores across the cell membrane 1
Transporter facilitate movement of solutes down their concentration gradient or move solutes against their concentration gradient by using energy generated by moving another ion down its concentration gradient
Pumps use metabolic energy in the form of ATP to move ions up their concentration gradient Integral membrane proteins with multiple membrane spanning α helical domains Effectively 'wrap' the solute in a protein sheath creating a pore across the lipid bilayer One or more specific binding site are located in the pore facilitating selective binding and passage of solutes Major Structural difference between channels and transporters/pump Number of gates
Ion channel: can function with one gates Transporter/pump: require two gates to function correctly only one gate can be opened at a time to prevent flow back of solutes Transportation rate cycling between states require conformational change and thus limiting the rate of transportation rate of transporter and pump Most ion channels in the cell membrane will closed most of the time Transporters and pumps are generally constitutively active maintain the balance between channel mediated ion fluxed down concentration gradients Water channels are always open Multi column In general animal cells High Intracellular concentration of K+ Low intracellular concentration of Na+ Very low intracellular concentration of Ca2+ High concentration of fixed anions → Net negative charge present an osmotic challenge for the cell maintenance of the unequal distribution of ions between the inside and outside of cell
essential to maintain osmotic balance and the integrity of the cell membrane A- = fixed anions → sum of all the negatively charged inorganic ions, proteins, and other organic molecules
multiple futile cycles of ion transport - pump in and out of the cell by different channel maintain osmotic balance ion gradients provide energy for the transport of other solutes and cell signaling (creating a concentration gradient that facilitate the transport of other solute against their conc. gradient) generate electrical signal through current flow through ion channels chemical signaling via the influx of calcium ions into the cytoplasm

item.title: Evolutionary Biology
item.description:
LUCA: Last Universal Common Ancestor ~ 3.5 billion years ago Igt: lateral gene transfer impermeable and continuous cell membrane defines intracellular vs extracellular space
Importance of Cell Membrane in evolution allows the cell to concentrate useful resources inside the cell restrict sharing novel proteins and metabolic products allows effective patent of any novel innovations in the cell's genetic material
Creating potential for Darwinian evolution a steady flux of energy from the environment is required for a life to start
counteract the second law of thermodynamic Entropy of an isolated system always increases. Cells inevitably break down over time and a continuous flux of energy is required for maintain and repair of cells, growth and reproduce Equation = Change in enthalpy a measure of heat given off or taken up = Change in entropy > 0 = more disordered < 0 = more ordered a negative is required either produce an increase in entropy () or or a large degrease in enthalpy () that exceeds the local entropy Evolutionary history First cells harnessed geochemical energy through the oxidation or reduction compounds from water-rock reactions Later, reduced carbon compounds from dead cells and cellular waste products would have been available for oxidation Anoxygenic photosynthetic reaction began to utilize sunlight as an energy source Oxygenic photosynthesis (produce oxygen) gradual buildup of oxygen in the atmosphere and ocean greatly increasing the amount of energy available to the biosphere
Cellular Respiration generation of ion gradients -> form ATP utilize oxygen Respiration - generation of ion gradient which allow the formation of ATP more effective than fermentation primary energy generating pathway by only a few organisms Anaerobic respiration predates aerobic respiration there was little to no free oxygen in the atmosphere and oceans prior to the evolution of oxygenic photosynthesis Aerobic respiration evolved first in prokaryotes Fermentation - formation of ATP solely by enzymatic pathways Permeability of membrane for efficient energy production, membrane must be at least sodium (in most cases also hydrogen) impermeant
Early cells most likely had a lipid bilayer membrane with low permeability to most charged and polar solutes
Multiple specific solute transport system evolved early to move solutes in and out of the cell evidence shows that LUCA had a Na+/H+ antiporter Membrane potential mitochondria have a large electrical potential across the inner membrane (~150mV) membrane potential exceeds approximately 200mV the electric field produces dielectric breakdown creating holes in membrane favors the evolve of ion channels to stabilize membrane potential most like to be channel selective against protons and/or sodium to avoid the degrading of ion gradient
Potassium Channel potassium selective channels for membrane potential stabilization result in high concentration of internal K+ It is possible that the most biochemical system evolved to become dependent on high potassium concentraion enzyme system and packing of nucleic acids depend on high potassium ion

item.title: Potassium channel
item.description:
Tetramers - Each subunit has three prominent α helices - 2 of them are membrane spanning: inner and outer helix - a pore helix located near the extracellular surface of the channel - both terminals located on the cytoplasmic side Minimize energy barrier for efficient ion movement a wide water-filled pore connecting to the narrow selective filter K+ ion travel 70% of the channels while retaining their hydration shell pore helices are positioned to maximize the helix-dipole effect mimicking hydration shell → reduce energy barrier Selectivity of K+ channel highly selective for K+ over Na+ by a ration of 10,000:1 conserved amino acid sequence of selective filter: TVGYG AA arranged to form a straight line, side chain facing out and carbonyl oxygen atom facing pore forming five oxygen rings → four K+ binding sites oxygen atoms facing the K+ ion replace the oxygen atoms from water molecule of the inner hydration shell Na+ ion has a smaller ionic radius → doesn't fit as well into the selective filter → higher energy barrier Ion permeation two K+ passing each time due to electrostatic repulsion
channel cycle between two semi-stable states no significant rearrangement involved → can cycle rapidly

item.title: cell volume
item.description:
primarily determined by the volume of intracellular and extracellular solutions water flow into or out of the cell across the cell membrane through aquaporin a measure of the concentration of osmotically active particles in a solution expressed as osmoles of solute per liter of solution Osmolarity For molecules that do not dissociate, e.g. glucose, urea, sucrose 1 L of water containing 1 mol of molecules is 1 osmole/L For solts or acids dissolved in solution osmolarity depends on the number of ions the molecule will dissociated into e.g. 1M NaCl solution is a 2 osmole/L solution e.g. 2M CaCl2 solution is a 6 osmole/L solution maintaining a balanced osmolarity between inside and outside of the cell is important for maintaining integrity and limit potential damage to the cell membrane Osmolarity of the extracellular solution is kept within relatively tight limit 275 - 295 mosmole/L in mammals
Changing of concentration of water outside of the cell will cause cells to shrink or burst water flow down its concentration if osmolarity inside the cell is much higher than outside i.e. water concentration is higher outside than inside water flow into the cell and causing rapid expands and dies

self-assembly of lipid bilayer in aqueous environment proton are unstable in aqueous solution and almost instantly react with surrounding water molecule Hydronium ions contribute to the low electrical conductivity of pure water proton hopping protons jumping from one water molecules to another creating current flow and movement of protons through pure water Aquaporins, water channels, minimize proton hopping preventing unregulated pathway for movement of proton cross the membrane Water has a concentration concentration of H2O molecules in pure water is approximately 55.5M if sugar molecules are added to pure water the concentration of water per liter decrease as sugar molecules take up some space in a liter of solution

item.title: Solutes
